Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Hybrid Continuous-Discrete Computers for Cyber-Physical Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research aims at hybrid (discrete-continuous) computation for cyber-physical systems. The research augments the today-ubiquitous discrete (digital) model of computation with continuous (analog) computing, which is well-suited to the continuous natural variables involved in cyber-physical systems, and to the error-tolerant nature of computation in such systems. The result is a computing platform on a single silicon chip, with higher energy efficiency, higher speed, and better numerical convergence than is possible with purely discrete computation. The research has several thrusts: (1) Hardware: modern silicon chip technology is used to merge analog computing hardware on the same chip with digital hardware, the latter used for control and co-computation, (2) Architecture: methods are devised for making hybrid computing functionality accessible to the software, (3) Microarchitecture: Choices are made on the granularity, type and organization of analog and hybrid analog-digital functional units, and (4) Concrete application to a realistic cyber-physical system consisting of a team of robots.

The research extends modern computer architecture techniques, and advances in mixed analog/digital chip technology mainly developed in the context of communications, to hybrid computing for cyber-physical systems. It brings higher levels of energy efficiency to error-tolerant workloads that future computers will have to handle. The techniques developed can be extended to other systems in which efficient computation is a must, such as weather forecasting and high-energy physics. The work integrates research with education and includes plans for broad dissemination of the results obtained.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a significant demand today to improve the energy efficiency and programmability of emerging,

transformative hardware devices and their usage. In this proposal, we have investigated whether this demand can be met, at least in part, by using computation that combines the techniques of the modern digital computer with those of its predecessor, the analog computer. The analog computer operates with continuous variables, i.e. in the manner most physical phenomena evolve; it thus represents a natural way to handle the mathematical representations that describe such phenomena. Combining this approach with modern digital techniques, which naturally support sequencing, creates an intuitive and easy-to-use computing model. The resulting, mixed analog/digital computer is called a “hybrid computer”. While hybrid computers were investigated in the 1960s and 1970s, they were using the limited technology of the time, and were abandoned back then in favor of digital computers. What we did in this project was to re-visit hybrid techniques but in the context of modern silicon chip technology – in fact, the same technology being used for modern digital computers. The result combines, in a sense, the best of both worlds.

To make hybrid computing a reality, we adopted a research agenda that spanned the areas of computer architecture and circuit design. While analog circuits are more susceptible to noise compared to digital circuits, we sought to overcome this problem by leveraging the error tolerance that is inherent in many emerging application domains, e.g., the modeling of physics for such applications as cyber-physical systems, which tightly couple those systems to computing. In addition, we sought to use the resulting approximate analog solution as a “seed solution” that can be refined by a digital solver to produce accurate answers.

We have produced two silicon chips that have confirmed the validity of our approach. Compared to similar digital micro-controllers, for the same accuracy, our computer can solve certain mathematical problems in less than one-tenth the time, and with less than one-tenth the energy consumption.

 Intellectual Merit: The research extends modern computer architecture techniques, and advances in mixed analog/digital chip technology mainly developed in the context of communications, to hybrid computing for cyber-physical systems. It brings higher levels of energy efficiency to error-tolerant workloads that future computers will have to handle. This work necessitated the design of original computing blocks, to take special advantage of the possibilities of today’s silicon chip technology. This includes the use of extensive digital calibration techniques to null out the inaccuracies of analog circuits, as well as the design of computer memories that operate in continuous time. We have also investigated the use of our hybrid computer as an accelerator to a digital computer. Our results are now being broadly disseminated.

Broader Impact: The successful completion of the project brings higher levels of energy efficiency to error-tolerant workloads that future computers have to handle. The techniques developed can be extended to other systems in which efficient computation is a must, such as weather forecasting and high-energy physics. Some of our results have been incorporated into courses we teach, thus helping to integrate research with education.
